docs.snippet: The wife of a former Enron executive has asked that her criminal trial be held outside Houston because a jury could be tainted by the extensive news coverage of Enron and the presence of investors and former employees who lost money.    Lea W. Fas...
docs.lead_paragraph: The wife of a former Enron executive has asked that her criminal trial be held outside Houston because a jury could be tainted by the extensive news coverage of Enron and the presence of investors and former employees who lost money. Lea W. Fastow, the wife of Andrew S. Fastow and a former Enron employee herself, has pleaded not guilty to a six-count indictment charging her with conspiracy to commit wire fraud, money laundering conspiracy and filing false tax returns.
docs.abstract: Lea W Fastow, wife of former Enron executive Andrew S Fastow and a former Enron employee herself, asks that her criminal trial be moved out of Houston because jury could be tainted by extensive news coverage of Enron and presence of investors and former employees who lost money; has pleaded not guilty to six-count indictment charging her with conspiracy to commit wire fraud, money laundering conspiracy and filing false tax returns (S)

headline.main: Judge Asked to Move Trial in Enron Case

docs.snippet: Former executives of the Enron Corporation have been sued by a group of workers seeking the return of $72 million in bonuses paid in the days surrounding the company's collapse in a record bankruptcy proceeding. Four lawsuits have been filed in fe...
docs.lead_paragraph: Former executives of the Enron Corporation have been sued by a group of workers seeking the return of $72 million in bonuses paid in the days surrounding the company's collapse in a record bankruptcy proceeding. Four lawsuits have been filed in federal bankruptcy court in Houston against 292 former employees, officers and executives of the energy company by the Enron Employee-Related Issues Committee, a panel named in Enron's bankruptcy case. The lawsuits come as Enron is trying to advance a reorganization plan filed this month that might allow it to emerge from bankruptcy by year's end.
docs.abstract: Panel representing Enron employees in company's bankruptcy case sues 292 former employees, officers and executives for return of $72 million in bonuses paid them in days surrounding company's collapse (S)

headline.main: ENRON WORKERS SUE OVER BONUSES PAID TO EXECUTIVES

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it planned to form a company for most of its overseas utilities, power plants and pipelines, ending an effort to auction the assets. The new company, temporarily named InternationalCo, will be governed by ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it planned to form a company for most of its overseas utilities, power plants and pipelines, ending an effort to auction the assets. The new company, temporarily named InternationalCo, will be governed by an independent board and will be protected from liabilities related to the bankruptcy, Enron said. The assets include 19 companies in 12 countries and Guam, including Elektro, an electric utility in Brazil, and SK-Enron, the largest natural gas distributor in South Korea. Enron said in August that it would auction the assets to help repay more than $50 billion in debts. After reviewing bids, Enron decided to keep the businesses, a spokesman, John Ambler, said. About 8,000 of Enron's 12,000 employees will become part of the new company, Mr. Ambler said.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp says it will form company, temporarily named InternationalCo, for most of its overseas assets, ending effort to auction assets; company will be governed by independent board and protected from liabilities related to Enron bankruptcy; about 8,000 of Enron's 12,000 employees will become part of new company (S)

headline.main: ENRON PLANS NEW COMPANY FOR OVERSEAS ASSETS

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Company Man to the End, After All'' (Feb. 9) says the stock-selling patterns of Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron, showed that he ''retained his faith in the company virtually until its collapse'':    If reluc...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Company Man to the End, After All'' (Feb. 9) says the stock-selling patterns of Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron, showed that he ''retained his faith in the company virtually until its collapse'': If reluctant stock sales are the proof of good-faith behavior, then so is the willingness of a captain to go down with his ship after steering its course for an iceberg.
docs.abstract: Doug Lane letter on Kenneth Lay's sale of Enron stock

headline.main: Those Delayed Sales Of Enron Stock

docs.snippet: Seeking to allay questions about Gov. John G. Rowland's possible involvement in its failed $220 million deal with Enron last year, Connecticut's state trash authority today released a series of executive memos that made no mention of the governor ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to allay questions about Gov. John G. Rowland's possible involvement in its failed $220 million deal with Enron last year, Connecticut's state trash authority today released a series of executive memos that made no mention of the governor nor any hint that he might have known about the deal. William E. Curry Jr., Mr. Rowland's Democratic opponent in the governor's race, has made the deal a campaign centerpiece, and insisted that the four memos be released.
docs.abstract: Connecticut's state trash authority releases series of memos on failed $220 million deal with Enron; Democratic gubernatorial candidate William E Curry Jr has made Enron involvement centerpiece of campaign, but memos do not mention Rowland or give any hint of involvement in deal (S)

headline.main: Memos on Enron Deal Released; No Mention of Rowland Role

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Paul Krugman (column, Sept. 17) refers to evidence in Enron documents that ''indicates that Mr. Cheney's handpicked Army secretary was a corporate evildoer.'' Mr. Krugman says a reporter, Jason Leopold, is writing a book about th...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman (column, Sept. 17) refers to evidence in Enron documents that ''indicates that Mr. Cheney's handpicked Army secretary was a corporate evildoer.'' Mr. Krugman says a reporter, Jason Leopold, is writing a book about the California energy crisis and ''has graciously shared his evidence with me. It's quite damning.''
docs.abstract: Letter from Army Sec Thomas E White says he does not recall saying or writing anything close to quote attributed to him in Paul Krugman's Sept 17 Op-Ed about Enron Corp

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation is seeking permission to bundle some of its core assets to form a smaller energy company that could be spun off by the end of the year as a separate unit operating outside the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.    E...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation is seeking permission to bundle some of its core assets to form a smaller energy company that could be spun off by the end of the year as a separate unit operating outside the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. Enron executives, who have been floating such an idea for weeks, made a formal proposal today to creditors in the bankruptcy case in New York. They said the new company would operate with about $10 billion in assets and would offer the best opportunity for creditors to ''maximize recoveries.''
docs.abstract: Enron Corp is seeking permission from creditors to bundle some of its core assets to form smaller energy company that could be spun off by end of year as separate unit operating outside company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings; executives say new company would operate with about $10 billion in assets and would offer best opportunity for creditors to 'maximize recoveries'; interim chief executive Stephen F Cooper comments (M)

headline.main: Enron Officials Propose to Spin Off a Smaller Energy Concern

docs.snippet: Ask if this city is going through a bust and receive a classic Texas response: We've seen bigger.    Memories of the mid-1980's, when the local economy ran dry, haunt Houston. In the late 1970's, Houston's office market benefited from economic fac...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ask if this city is going through a bust and receive a classic Texas response: We've seen bigger. Memories of the mid-1980's, when the local economy ran dry, haunt Houston. In the late 1970's, Houston's office market benefited from economic factors that were hurting the rest of the country. The Arab oil embargo, the Iran hostage situation and a recession helped make oil drilling wildly profitable. Developers added 31 million square feet of office space from 1975 to 1979, and another 84.2 million from 1980 to 1984.
docs.abstract: Houston, Tex, economy is going through some hard econmic times since collapse of Enron Corp but city has witnessed worse problems in mid-1980's (M)

headline.main: A City Always on a Wave

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Longtime Clients Abandon Auditor'' (front page, March 16) says the partnership contracts at Arthur Andersen include noncompetition clauses. If the firm dissolves, look to these clauses as the reason.
docs.abstract: John A Clark letter disputes March 16 article on financial outlook for partners of Arthur Andersen ifcompany is forced to dissolve because of Enron scandal

docs.snippet: Wading into what is expected to be a major battle of the 2002 midterm elections, President Bush today promoted his plan to let workers invest part of their Social Security money in the stock market.    Mr. Bush also spoke out for pension changes i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Wading into what is expected to be a major battle of the 2002 midterm elections, President Bush today promoted his plan to let workers invest part of their Social Security money in the stock market. Mr. Bush also spoke out for pension changes in the wake of the filing for bankruptcy protection by Enron that cost thousands of workers their retirement savings but left top executives with millions of dollars from selling the company's stock.
docs.abstract: Pres Bush renews his push for partial privatization of Social Security that would let workers invest some money in stock market; also speaks out for pension reform measures in wake of Enron Corp bankruptcy that cost thousands of workers their retirement savings but left top executives with millions of dollars from selling company's stock; Democrats criticize Social Security plan as irresponsible, saying it would cut deeply into guaranteed benefits and create unacceptable financial risks for retirees; photo (M)

headline.main: Bush Renews Push to Partly Privatize Social Security
